title-group.article-title: Single-Incision Laparoscopic Resection of Bismuth I Hilar Cholangiocarcinoma

article-meta.aff: 1Shengjing Hospital, China Medical University, Shenyang, China

author-notes.corresp: Shuo-dong Wu, Department of General Surgery, First Minimally Invasive and Biliary Surgery Unit, Shengjing Hospital, China Medical University, Shenyang 110004, People’s Republic of China. Email: yuhong1973@163.com

abstract.p: Introduction. Laparoscopic hilar cholangiocarcinoma is rarely performed because of its aggressive growth and complicated anatomy. The authors successfully performed single-incision laparoscopic resection of Bismuth I hilar cholangiocarcinoma in 2 cases. Method. Two cases with Bismuth I cholangiocarcinoma were chosen for the laparoscopic surgery. Segmental bile duct resection and hepatoduodenal ligament lymphadenectomy were performed using single-incision laparoscopic technique with conventional instruments. Results. Two operations were successfully performed without conversion. The operation time was 300 and 350 minutes, respectively. The margins of proximal and distal bile ducts were negative. The hospital stay was 6 and 9 days, respectively. One dosage of analgesic was administered after surgery. The abdominal wound recovered very well with good cosmesis. Conclusion. Single-incision laparoscopic surgery cholangiocarcinoma resection can be optional in strictly selected patients with Bismuth I cholangiocarcinoma. Long-term follow-up and more data are needed to evaluate its benefits.

body.p: Since the first-reported laparoscopic cholecystectomy performed through a single umbilical incision in 1997,1 the single-incision laparoscopic surgery (SILS) technique has been applied to several different surgeries including cholecystectomy,2 appendectomy,3 sleeve gastrectomy,4 colectomy,5 and splenectomy,6 and others. Although still in its preliminary stage, SILS has shown some advantages in cosmesis and reduced postoperative pain.

Hilar cholangiocarcinoma is rarely performed by laparoscopy because most of hilar cholangiocarcinomas require hilar resection combined with extended hepatectomy, which is technically challenging. Nonetheless, segmental bile duct resection is still an option for some limited Bismuth I hilar cholangiocarinoma and middle bile duct cancer as long as R0 resection can be achieved.7 Under laparoscopy, bile duct resection with lymphadenectomy is preferred to extended hepatectomy. We had previously reported8 of conventional multiport laparoscopic resection of cholangiocarcinoma in specifically selected patients. We report herein the use of the SILS technique with traditional instruments in 2 patients undergoing cholangiocarcinoma resection.

sec.title: Patients and Methods
sec.p: This study reports on 2 cases, women aged 54 and 60 years, presenting with complaints of jaundice with abdominal distension. Abdominal ultrasonography, 64-contrast computer tomography, and magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography were performed to achieve a diagnosis, classification, and staging. According to radiographic imaging, both lesions were located around the confluence of the cystic duct, common hepatic duct, and common bile duct. The upper margin of each lesion was about 2 cm away from the bifurcation of the left and right hepatic bile duct. The preoperative direct bilirubin was 296.4 and 150.0 µmol/L, respectively. No biliary drainage was performed before surgery.

The patients were placed in the supine position with legs apart under general anesthesia. The surgeon stood between the legs of the patient. The conventional laparoscopic instruments were used. After pneumoperitonium was established, a 12-mm trocar was placed in the umbilical area for camera access. No remarkable metastasis was found through careful laparoscopic exploration. The umbilical incision was enlarged to 2 cm, without cutting the anterior sheath of rectus abdominis. Two other 5-mm trocars were positioned in the same incision. One was for assistant manipulation, and the other was for major handling such as dissection and division (Figure 1).

caption.p: The umbilical incision and the position of trocars.

sec.p: The procedure was as follows: First, the gallbladder was removed from the liver bed without transecting the cystic duct. Then, the common hepatic duct was transected right below the bifurcation of the right and left hepatic ducts. The distal common hepatic duct was retracted caudally. Lymph nodes and connective tissues in the hepatoduodenal ligament were removed using a 5-mm harmonic scalpel (Ethicon Endo-Surgery, Inc, Cincinnati, OH) until the proper hepatic artery and portal vein were skeletonized (Figure 2). Dissection was further extended caudally until the common bile duct was transected at the upper margin of the pancreas. En bloc specimen was put in a bag and retrieved from the incision, then sent for frozen-section histological examination to ensure negative margins of both proximal and distal bile ducts. The procedures were completed intracorporeally with laparoscopic reconstruction of the biliary tree with Roux-en-Y choledocho-jejunostomy. The biliary enteric anastomosis was completed by running suture. The entero-enteric anastomosis was performed via Endo GIA (Covidien, Mansfield, MA). First, the Treitz ligament was identified, and the jejunum 20 cm distal to Treiz ligament was divided using an Endo GIA. When the Endo GIA was inserted from the 12-mm trocar, we decided to use 5-mm camera temporarily. Then, the Roux-en-Y loop was retrocolically pulled up to the hepatic hilum. An end-to-side choledochojejunostomy was performed at the hilum by a single-layer running suture of 5–0 PDS (Figures 3 and 4). A 40-cm Roux-en-Y limb and jejunojejunostomy were created intracorporeally. After 2 small enterotomies were made in proximal and distal jejunum, the Endo GIA was introduced and fired (Figure 5). The common enterotomy was closed with intracorporeal sutures.

caption.p: The skeletonization of the hepatoduodenal ligament.
The beginning of the cholangiojejunal anastomosis.
The end of the cholangiojejunal anastomosis.

sec.p: One drainage tube was placed around the anastomosis of choledochojejunumy and pulled out through the umbilical incision. Closure of umbilical incision was performed using polydioxanone sutures to the abdominal fascia. The skin was closed by absorbable monofilament sutures.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The histopathology exhibited well-differentiated adenocarcinoma in one case and mild differentiation in the other. The proximal and distal margins of the bile ducts were free from malignant cells. In these 2 cases, 3 to 4 lymph nodes were harvested without showing evidence of malignancy. The operation time was 300 and 350 minutes, respectively. The bleeding during the surgery was 350 and 400 mL, respectively. One dose analgesic (pethidine 100 mg IM) was administered 4 hours after surgery. Both patients were out of bed on postoperative day 2 and recovered bowel activities on days 3 and 4, respectively. In one case, bile leakage occurred. About 200 mL bile leakage lasted 5 days and stopped on day 6. Drainage tubes were removed on days 3 and 7, and the patients were discharged on days 6 and 9, respectively. The wound recovered very well without obvious scar on the abdominal wall (Figure 6).

caption.p: The umbilical scar after surgery without other abdominal scars.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Although data showed that extended hepatectomy can achieve more R0 resection, given the high morbidity and mortality rates for these procedures, the long-term survival rates did not increase significantly.9-11 The extent of resection for Bismuth I cholangiocarcinoma and middle bile duct cancer still remains controversial. Hyung Geun Lee reported7 bile duct segmental resection with hepatoduodenal ligament lymphadenectomy achieved better survival compared with pancretoduodenectomy (PD). Sakamoto et al12 compared extrahepatic bile duct resection and extended right hemihepatectomy to treat cholangiocarcinoma, and could not conclude that the extensive hepatectomy was necessary for Bismuth I and II cholangiocarcinoma. R0 resection was believed by most of the investigators to be the most important independent factor for radical resection.13-15 As long as R0 resection can be achieved, the segmental bile duct resection of Bismuth I cholangiocarcinoma and middle bile duct cancer can get acceptable survival rates with less morbidity and mortality. According to the preoperative imaging, we chose 2 patients with the lesion limited to the hepatic bile duct. The upper margin of the lesion was about 2 cm from the bifurcation of the right and left hepatic bile ducts. No metastasis and vessel invasion were found. Exploration and dissection under laparoscopy were helpful to find metastasis and remarkable invasion out of bile duct. If metastasis or vessel invasion was found during the laparoscopic exploration, conversion to open surgery or laparoscopic palliative surgery was the option. Goere et al16 reported laparoscopy increased the accuracy of preoperative staging for some cholangiocarcinomas. Although laparoscopic intraoperative ultrasound has been applied to some liver, pancreas, and biliary tract diseases and shown to have some advantages,17-19 it is limited because of its strong dependence on the experience of the surgeon, the amount of time taken, and the increased cost of treatment.20 It is not clear if laparoscopic intraoperative ultrasound is valuable in the preoperative staging and intraoperative guidance of surgery in cases with hilar cholangiocarcinoma.

During surgery we first transected the common hepatic duct close to the bifurcation of the right and left hepatic bile ducts, so that we could further confirm that the proximal bile duct margin was some distance away from the tumor.

It is important not to injure the hepatic artery and portal vein during removal of the connective tissues in the hepatoduodenal ligament because it is more difficult to stop bleeding in SILS procedure than in conventional laparoscopic surgery or open surgery. After transection of the common hepatic duct, biliary reconstruction was performed. The biliary enteric anastomosis was completed by running suture. To avoid bile leakage after surgery, we sutured the bile duct wall with some surrounding connective tissue so that the anastomosis was not as vulnerable to tearing. The jejunojejunal anastomosis was performed completely incorporeally using line staple and accomplished by suture of the enteromy. The method we followed was not as complicated as we expected it to be. Tang et al21 exteriorized the jejunum and completed the anastomosis excorporeally. Although it can decrease the cost without using another staple, the opening has to be big enough to pull out the jejunum.

As is well known, the loss of triangulation because of the instruments being present in the same incision made SILS more challenging.22-25 Clashing of the instruments during surgery made coordination between the surgeon and assistant more important. Advanced procedures should build on the experiences of SILS in basic procedures such as cholecystectomy. So far we have performed about 800 cases of SILS cholecystectomy, appendectomy, and hernia fixation.26 In addition, the introduction of novel instruments such as articulated instruments and a long-arm laparoscope will facilitate the procedure in the future.

Although SILS bile duct resection did not show remarkable advantages on the operation time and bleeding during the surgery compared with the conventional laparoscopic surgery or open surgery of the same procedure, we think they are acceptable in the initial stage. The recovery time and postoperative hospital stays were slightly shorter than for the conventional laparoscopic methods but much shorter than for open surgery. Reduced analgesic administration after the surgery was an apparent advantage compared with conventional laparoscopic and open surgery. The cosmesis was another advantage. Except for a small scar around the navel, it was scarless. The patients were well satisfied with the results. Because no specially designed instruments were used in our SILS technique, the cost of the surgery did not increase. As for complication, there was bile leakage in one case without negative outcome except for the slightly longer hospital stay.

In summary, this is the first time we have used the SILS technique for a cholangiocarcinoma resection. For some strictly selected patients with type I cholangiocarcinoma, it is feasible and safe. Long-term follow-up is needed to determine whether the patients can benefit from SILS.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Single-incision laparoscopic cholangiocarcinoma resection can be optional in strictly selected patients with Bismuth I cholangiocarcinoma. Long-term follow-up and more data are needed to evaluate its benefits.
